SENT.plain: A rare case of CNS Burkitt's lymphoma presenting as acute Guillain-Barré syndrome is presented
A 6-year-old previously healthy female presented with acute onset of limb and truncal weakness, involvement of ocular and bulbar nerves, and areflexia
The clinical diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome prompted treatment with intravenous gammaglobulin with no response
A lumbar puncture following revealed marked pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose
Immunological, cytological, and molecular studies of these cells confirmed the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma IgM, kappa with t(8;14) and rearrangement of the J and kappa immunoglobulin chains
Aggressive systemic and intrathecal chemotherapy were started and within 5 days remission was achieved
The child is in complete remission 2 years from diagnosis
Although very rare, CNS lymphoma should be taken into account in every patient presenting with the clinical features of acute polyneuropathy
